author: Monique Pryce

text: A beautiful example of analog synths.
author: Echo_Hotel

text: I just recently discovered about vocaloids. Do you think this could be using that technology for the vocal phrasing. Also I hear those voices as maybe being vocoded, not really anything built from waves like an analog synth
author: 1afoohs1

text:
@1afoohs1 Katamari Damacy came out in Japan on March 2004, the first commercial version of Vocaloid came out January 2004. Now it's not impossible that Yuu Miyake somehow got his hands on a pre-release version of the software I doubt it would have turned out great .
For your second bit, at the risk of sounding like a stoned college student, it's all waves man. With enough filter modules and patch cables an analog synth IS a vocoder. That sort of sharp, chirpy, sibilance, that is part of the vocal track points to simpler analog filters rather than infinitely adjustable digital ones.
I think . . .
maybe

text:
A katamari... cat-amari... this is what you collected the most off.
It feels... fluffyish... and... fuzzy. Not that we know if that's a good thing.
author: Luxai

text: The notes in brilliant fugue stand against each other just as the king's wise reign stands against his magnanimous inner nature. Both move in perfect harmony with respect of each other, in accordance with the rules of counterpoint. An infinitely difficult puzzle only the most intelligent, creative and sincere of composers can solve. We are blessed with the existence of such music. To hear it, you only need to have an ear for the cosmos! Your loving king is always there playing for you.
author: Farco

text: Fairly complex fugue, having four voices at most, with beginning of the second part actually starting with two subjects, (one as a voice and one as a harpsichord), though not being a double fugue. It even has five voices towards the end.

text: I think this is actually from the second game (We Love Katamari.) To make things even more confusing, it wasn't actually included on that OST, but on the OST for the third game (Me & My Katamari)

text:
@Hayden Hawley For some reason, they omitted a lot of tracks from Katamari wa Damacy, even the tracks that play during a montage for The King and Queen and when The King, Queen and Papa hang out.
It's also pretty weird how they didn't add the new track they made for talking with The King into the Me & My Katamari OST.
